Title: The です form
Lecon: The “です” form is used for everything and can be translated by “be”. “<color="blue">X</color> is <color="green">Y</color>” is translated in “<color="blue">X</color>は<color="green">Y</color>です”. In this situation ‘は’, is called a particle, it’s here to indicate the grammatical structure of the sentence, the ‘は’ is used to identify the topic of a sentence.
Examples: <color="blue">Today</color> <color="red">is</color> <color="green">Monday</color>|<color="blue">今日</color>は<color="green">月曜日</color><color="red">です</color>|<color="blue">I</color>’<color="red">m</color> <color="green">Chloé</color> (クロエ)|<color="blue">私</color>は<color="green">クロエ</color><color="red">です</color>|<color="blue">I</color>’<color="red">m</color> <color="green">French</color> (フランス)|<color="blue">私</color>は<color="green">フランス人</color><color="red">です</color>

Title: The です form
Lecon: In order to use the negative form of “です”, you simply transforme “です” into “ではありません”. ONCE AGAIN ‘は’ is prononce like ‘わ’.
Examples: <color="blue">Today</color> <color="red">is not</color> <color="green">Monday</color>|<color="blue">今日</color>は<color="green">月曜日</color><color="red">ではありません</color>|<color="blue">I</color>’<color="red">m not</color> <color="green">Chloé</color> (クロエ)|<color="blue">私</color>は<color="green">クロエ</color><color="red">ではありません</color>|<color="blue">I</color>’<color="red">m not</color> <color="green">French</color> (フランス)|<color="blue">私</color>は<color="green">フランス人</color><color="red">ではありません</color>

Title: The です form
Lecon: Finally, if you want to ask a question, you just add ‘か’ at the end of your sentence, be it, an affirmative or a negative sentence.
